Title.evidence: Randomised Controlled Trial of Preoperative Inorganic Nitrate in Cardiac Surgery

Trial_Design.evidence: single-centre, randomised, double-blind, placebo-controlled trial included 82 patients

Participants.evidence: Conducted at a Swedish hospital, this single-centre, randomised, double-blind, placebo-controlled trial included 82 patients aged 18-80 years scheduled for coronary artery bypass grafting with cardiopulmonary bypass. Exclusion criteria encompassed pregnancy, re-do surgery, and significant organ disease.

Intervention.evidence: Participants were randomised in blocks of four to receive either oral sodium nitrate (700 mg×2) or placebo (NaCl) before surgery.

Objective.evidence: This trial assessed whether preoperative inorganic nitrate could reduce troponin T release and other organ injury biomarkers in patients undergoing cardiac surgery.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was troponin T release over 72 hours postoperatively.

Blinding.evidence: all participants, clinicians, and outcome assessors were blinded

Number_Randomised.evidence: Ninety-five patients were randomised, with 42 in the placebo group and 40 in the nitrate group completing the study.

Number_Analysed.evidence: Ninety-five patients were randomised, with 42 in the placebo group and 40 in the nitrate group completing the study.

Result_Outcome.evidence: The 72-hour troponin T release showed no significant difference between groups (p=0.19).

Harms.evidence: no significant differences in adverse events between groups.

Funding.evidence: Funding: The trial was supported by institutional grants.
